Tim -- science is done by human beings ... with human frailties.

To err is human, etc. The point of science is not that individuals are such perfect scientists or exhibit godly restraint and wisdom ... but that the whole of science is quite efficient at correcting errors ... in anything of reasonable importance.

Almost every scientist has made dumb mistakes, and we know it. Those who have some common sense circulate a draft of whatever is their current enthusiasm around among friendly reviewers ... who sometimes do what a friend really ought to ... point out that you're wrong before you truly embarrass yourself.

I've pulled a manuscript before it got into print -- not because the journal reviewers caught the error ... but because one of my buddies did. I had to redo the whole thing and it became a much less grand paper ... that's the way it goes....

Well, let us count the ways:

Evidence based does sentence by who they are. That grows out of the "career criminal" idea, and a dream of identifying them before they hurt victims.

Worse, it will sentence based on things not proven, even things found "not guilty." The standard of proof for sentencing is lower than for guilt. A defendant can win a trial except for one count, and still be sentenced for all the crimes of which he was just found not guilty. And it happens, often.

"Many drug companies have little interest in devising treatments or vaccines for Ebola because the potential for profit is small. Much of the research has been financed by the National Institutes of Health and the Department of Defense and carried out by small start-ups, but some experts believe the federal government has not shown enough urgency to push these programs ahead."

That's the problem in a nutshell. If it isn't profitable enough, Big Pharma doesn't want to bother to get R&D money. And because it gets R&D money from the government, it can't justify its high prices.

Note to Josh Hill: I understand your point, but it would behoove all pharmaceutical companies in any country to find a cure for every rare tropical disease. Why? Because of imported produce and lack of proper inspection at US borders and customs. Also because that might lead to a better understanding of how pharmaceuticals work with various diseases.
